title: Brave Haringey showed the way forward for England
text:

In the end it took a non-league team to prove there is no room for racism.

Haringey Borough backed their talk with action by showing principle matters more than progress on the pitch.

They aren’t the first, but let’s hope they’ve provided us with a watershed moment to spark lasting change.

You’ll know the details by now: during Saturday’s FA Cup fourth-round qualifying game with Yeovil, Haringey keeper Douglas Pajetat was targeted by fans along with his team-mate Coby Rowe.

Boss Tom Loizou reacted by taking his players off the pitch. Yeovil followed in solidarity.

(Image: James Fearn/PPAUK)

(Image: James Fearn/PPAUK)

No worrying about the score or leaving it to officials. No worrying about what the FA might do or how it might affect the competition. Direct action. Enough.

Theirs was a real statement, in stark contrast to the bizarre triumphalism last Monday night in Bulgaria where England claimed some sort of moral victory. There was something of the Emperor’s New Clothes around the claim, widely accepted, from the top of the FA that the Three Lions had somehow made a stand by highlighting an issue already well documented.

They finished the game and got out of Dodge, allowing UEFA to follow the tired old ineffectual procedure that gets them off the hook.

Haringey have given the FA a tough decision to make.

Do the governing body back them – as they should? Or will they do what they did to Padiham FC of the North West Counties League 12 months ago?

(Image: Action Images via Reuters)

That team walked off during a game against Congleton in protest at the racist abuse keeper Tony Aghayere had been receiving from members of the crowd. Padiham were the ones fined.

In April of this year FC Wymeswold striker Linford Harris was also fined – and hit with a 10-match ban – after he was racially abused by fans in a County Cup final against Cosby United. His team-mates had walked off the pitch in solidarity. They too were charged. Because, of course, they were the problem.

Steve Bruce, as Sheffield United manager in 1999, took his players off in an FA Cup tie against Arsenal because he didn’t get the ball back after kicking it out for an injured Arsenal player to be treated. He was rewarded with a replay.

We’d have all been behind England’s stars had they come off in Bulgaria. Gareth Southgate and his men would have set a standard for a new generation from the top of English football.

(Image: James Fearn/PPAUK)

Walking off would have sent a powerful message on behalf of clubs like Haringey and Padiham and men like Linford Harris. Instead the top of the game is still clinging to banners, slogans, hashtags, protocols, T-shirts and talk. Lots and lots of talk.

Still on TV, radio and in print we wring our hands and ask what can be done to boot out racism when we know the answer.

Dock points. Throw clubs and countries out of competitions. We’ve called for it for Bulgaria, Montenegro and countless others, let’s accept it for our English clubs in the cup competitions and our domestic leagues. Let’s not allow tribalism to replace the unity of the past week. In the Championship eight months ago Birmingham were hit with a nine-point deduction after being found guilty of breaking the Football League’s spending rules.

Bradford, Grays and Whyteleafe are among a number of clubs kicked out of domestic club competitions for fielding ineligible players.

If the authorities can’t be as tough on racism then players must continue to protect themselves by either walking off or agreeing to be taken off.

(Image: James Fearn/PPAUK)

For five decades they have either been let down or conditioned to believe you beat the racists by smashing five or six goals past the opposition.

That hasn’t worked for past generations and it isn’t working now. The young black men of English football must realise their collective strength, just as the #MeToo movement has empowered women across industry and entertainment.

Now, from the bottom of football’s food chain, Haringey Borough have laid the foundations for a new standard. Players must keep walking off as they have done – until football embraces its duty to protect them.
description: Haringey Borough walked off the pitch during their FA Cup tie with Yeovil Town after their players were targeted by racial abuse
